title: Nature therapy - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: Nature therapy Nature therapy, sometimes referred to as ecotherapy, forest therapy, forest bathing, grounding, earthing, Shinrin-Yoku or Sami Lok, is a practice that describes a broad group of techniques or treatments using nature to improve [mental](/wiki/Mental_health) or physical health. Spending time in nature has various [physiological](/wiki/Physiological) benefits such as relaxation and [stress reduction](/wiki/Stress_reduction). Additionally, it can enhance cardiovascular health and lower blood pressure. [[1]](#cite_note-researchgate.net-1) [[2]](#cite_note-:2-2) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nature_therapy&action=edit§ion=1)] In the 6th century [BCE](/wiki/Common_Era), [Cyrus the Great](/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great) planted a garden in the middle of a city to increase human health. [[3]](#cite_note-Hansen2017-3) In the 16th century CE, [Paracelsus](/wiki/Paracelsus) wrote: "The art of healing comes from nature, not from the physician." [[4]](#cite_note-call-to-wild-4) Scientists in the 1950s looked into why people chose to spend time in nature. [[5]](#cite_note-:5-5) The term [Shinrin-yoku](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/shinrinyoku) () or forest bathing was coined by the head of the [Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries](/wiki/Ministry_of_Agriculture,_Forestry_and_Fisheries_(Japan)), Tomohide Akiyama, in 1982 to encourage more nature weekly could improve health and well-being. [[10]](#cite_note-10) As little as five minutes in a natural setting, improves mood, self-esteem, and motivation. [[11]](#cite_note-11) Nature therapy has a benefit in reducing stress and improving a person's mood. [[12]](#cite_note-12) [[13]](#cite_note-:0-13) People exposed to nature are also more cooperative and pleasant compared to those who are not. [[14]](#cite_note-14) Forest therapy has been linked to some physiological benefits as indicated by neuroimaging and the [Profile of mood states](/wiki/Profile_of_mood_states) psychological test. [[15]](#cite_note-15) Horticulture therapy has been linked to general well-being by boosting positive mood and escaping from daily life stressors. [[13]](#cite_note-:0-13) Stress and depression[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nature_therapy&action=edit§ion=4)] Interaction with nature can decrease stress and depression. [[1]](#cite_note-researchgate.net-1) [[13]](#cite_note-:0-13) [[3]](#cite_note-Hansen2017-3) [[16]](#cite_note-16) Forest therapy might help stress management for all age groups. [[17]](#cite_note-:10-17) Social horticulture could help with depression and other mental health problems of PTSD, abuse, lonely elderly people, drug or alcohol addicts, blind people, and other people with special needs. [[18]](#cite_note-18) Nature therapy could also improve self-management, self-esteem, social relations and skills, socio-political awareness and employability. [[19]](#cite_note-19) Nature therapy could reduce aggression and improve relationship skills. [[20]](#cite_note-:3-20) This is especially true due to the mental health damage COVID-19 brought. Nature therapy had significant results when it came to reducing stress, anxiety, and depression influenced by COVID-19. [[21]](#cite_note-21) Other possible benefits[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nature_therapy&action=edit§ion=5)] Nature therapy could help with general medical recovery, pain reduction, Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, dementia, obesity, and [vitamin D deficiency](/wiki/Vitamin_D_deficiency). [[22]](#cite_note-22) Interactions with nature environments enhance social connections, stewardship, sense of place, and increase environmental participation. [[23]](#cite_note-23) Connecting with nature also addresses needs such as intellectual capacity, emotional bonding, creativity, and imagination. [[24]](#cite_note-24) Overall, there seems to be benefits to time spent in nature including memory, cognitive flexibility, and attention control. [[25]](#cite_note-25) Research also suggests that childhood experience in nature are crucial for children in their daily lives as it contributes to several developmental outcomes and various domains of their well-being. Essentially, these experiences also foster an intrinsic care for nature. [[26]](#cite_note-26) Criticism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nature_therapy&action=edit§ion=6)] A 2012 systematic review study showed inconclusive results related to the methodology used in studies. [[27]](#cite_note-27) Spending time in forests demonstrated positive health effects, but not enough to generate clinical practice guidelines or demonstrate [causality](/wiki/Causality). [[28]](#cite_note-28) Additionally, there are concerns from researchers expressing that time spent in nature as a form of regenerative therapy is highly personal and entirely unpredictable. [[5]](#cite_note-:5-5) Nature can be harmed in the process of human interaction. [[5]](#cite_note-:5-5) Grounding[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nature_therapy&action=edit§ion=7)] Grounding, or earthing, is a pseudoscientific practice that involves people [grounding](/wiki/Ground_(electricity)) themselves using devices by touching the earth or removing shoes. [[29]](#cite_note-Mims_2012-29) [[30]](#cite_note-Kaufman_Kaufman_2019_p._207-30) People who ground themselves believe that they have been exposed to high levels of electromagnetic radiation. [[31]](#cite_note-31) Possible changes in mood could be due to a [placebo](/wiki/Placebo) effect. [[32]](#cite_note-32) Governmental support[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nature_therapy&action=edit§ion=8)] In Finland, researchers recommend five hours a month in nature to reduce depression, alcoholism, and [suicide](/wiki/Suicide_in_Finland). [[4]](#cite_note-call-to-wild-4) Forest therapy has state-backing in Japan. [[17]](#cite_note-:10-17) [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea) has a nature therapy program for firefighters with [post-traumatic stress disorder](/wiki/Post-traumatic_stress_disorder). [[4]](#cite_note-call-to-wild-4) Canadian physicians can also "prescribe nature" to patients with mental and physical health problems encouraging them to get into nature more.
